heading: 1 Introduction
text:
Main Concept Analysis (MCA) discourse assessment originally
developed Nicholas Brookshire (1995) measures 
informativeness discourse sample given topic. Main concept
checklists several widely used tasks (including picture description,
picture sequence, story retell, procedural stimuli) 
developed based discourse samples control speakers (Richardson &
Dalton, 2016; 2020). MCA hybrid discourse measure provides
information micro-linguistic features discourse sample 
well macro-linguistic features overall adequacy 
discourse sample communicate intended message.MCA shown good sensitivity differentiating controls 
individuals communication disorders (e.g., Kong, Whiteside, &
Bargmann, 2016; Dalton & Richardson, 2019) individuals 
fluent non-fluent aphasia (Kong et al., 2016). Importantly, studies
shown changes informativeness associated treatment
performance (Albright & Purves, 2008; Avent & Austermann, 2003; Coelho,
McHugh, & Boyle, 2000; Cupit, Rochon, Leonard, & Laird, 2010; Stark,
2010) associated listener’s perceptions communication
quality (Cupit et al., 2010; Ross & Wertz, 1999).main concept consists several essential elements,
corresponding subject, main verb, object (appropriate), 
subordinate clauses (Nicholas & Brookshire, 1995). main concept
assigned one 5 codes depending accuracy (essential
elements accurate?) completeness (essential elements present?)
production.

heading: 2 Coding & Scoring
text:
Coding:AC = accurate complete = contains elements main
> concept checklist incorrect information AC = accurate complete = contains elements main
> concept checklist incorrect information AI = accurate incomplete = contains incorrect information,
> leaves least one essential element main concept
> checklist AI = accurate incomplete = contains incorrect information,
> leaves least one essential element main concept
> checklist IC = inaccurate complete = contains least one incorrect piece
> essential information (e.g., “knight” “prince”) 
> includes essential elements main concept 
> checklist IC = inaccurate complete = contains least one incorrect piece
> essential information (e.g., “knight” “prince”) 
> includes essential elements main concept 
> checklist II = inaccurate incomplete = clearly corresponds main
> concept checklist includes least one incorrect
> essential element fails include least one essential
> element II = inaccurate incomplete = clearly corresponds main
> concept checklist includes least one incorrect
> essential element fails include least one essential
> element AB = absent = produce main conceptAB = absent = produce main conceptScoring*:*knowledge, norms AphasiaBank stimuli available
Richardson & Dalton 2016 scoring system. using Kong, 2009
system, scores compared Richardson & Dalton 2016 norms.
See Kong et al., 2016 main concepts, checklists, norms 
additional stimuli.Nicholas Brookshire also developed series coding rules 
assist determining accuracy completeness main concepts.
coding rules now supplemented published checklists,
provide common alternatives produced main concept, since
variability syntax vocabulary used 
produce main concept. alternative lists comprehensive,
possible client may produce acceptable alternative
checklist.Note Remember:Main concepts given transcript order shown main concept list.

happens ?”panel, response, provide prompt: “Can tell

ball window?”

heading: 5.2 Main Concept Checklist
text:
Essential information italicized bolded. essential
segment numbered (superscript) alternative productions (
produced) listed number . alternative productions 
intended exhaustive list represent 
common productions normative sample included aid 
scoring. Additional, non-essential, information often spoken 
complete main concept normal font. multiple utterances can
correspond MC, select best utterance presented 
purposes coding/scoring.
1.1The boy 2was 3outside.

since referent unambiguous; give boy name

, decided go

front yard, lawn, house, etc.

Note: Sometimes, concept combined number 2 statement like “boy playing soccer outside” “boy kicking ball yard.” statements receive full credit concept 1 2.

2.1A/boy 2was playing 3soccer.

See 1.1

Played, kicking, kicks, practicing, etc.

soccer ball, ball, football (U.S.)

Note: “ball” “soccer ball” count towards concept imply kind action soccer ball, boy-action-ball concept met criterion.

3.1The ball 2breaks 3the man’s/neighbor’s window.

Soccer ball, football***

Goes , went , crashes /, flew , sails /, shattered, kicked 

glass

4.1The man 2is sitting chair /inside house.

dad, father, father, neighbor, guy; give man name

Lounging, resting, relaxing, inside

Note: common “man sitting”, “man inside”, “man sitting inside”

Note: “man watching TV” something similar count concept; separate relevant concept meet criterion. However, individual said, “man sitting watching TV” receive credit concept since included “sitting.”

5.1The man 2was startled.

See 4.1

Surprised, amazed, afraid, astonished, freaked , stunned, shocked, angry, upset, happy, mad

Note: Occasionally, concept combined number 3, statement “ball crashed window startled man.”

See 3.1

Knocks /, smashes , breaks, hit

alternative lamp produced

7.1The man 2picked 3the ball.

See 4.1

Grabs, gets, holds/holding, catches, captures,

Note: Occasionally, “man stands ball” “man jumps ball” used express concept, expressing man performed action hold ball.

8.1The man 1looked 1out window.

See 4.1

Looks, looking

Outside, , glass

Note: “man goes window,” “man went window,” “man goes outside”, etc., count towards concept. separate relevant concepts meet criterion.

heading: 7.3 Metadata for sharing
text: Bookdown HTML books provide HTML metadata social sharing platforms like Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, using information provide index.Rmd YAML. setup, set url book path cover-image file. book’s title description also used.bs4_book provides enhanced metadata social sharing, chapter shared unique description, auto-generated based content.Specify book’s source repository GitHub repo _output.yml file, allows users view chapter’s source file suggest edit.
